Award.AwardTitle: Workshop: Understanding Emerging Technologies and the Future of Work

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intelligent, interactive, and highly networked machines are a growing part of work and the workplace. Automation is moving from the factory floor to knowledge and service occupations. The potential benefits of technology include increased productivity and more job opportunities. But technology connected to work can also carry substantial social costs. The workshop supported by this award will promote the convergence of education, social and behavioral sciences, computational sciences, and engineering with stakeholders. This diverse group will define key research challenges that focus on the intersection of humans, technology, and work. Convergence is the deep integration of knowledge, theories, methods, and data from multiple fields to form new and expanded frameworks for addressing scientific and societal challenges and opportunities. Two workshops will address the future of work at the human-technology frontier. The workshops will focus on the challenges of shaping emergent technologies that are equitable. They will also consider how the technologies will engage a wider range of people in the workforce of the future. The results of the workshops will include reports, communication materials, and the organization of interdisciplinary panels at professional scientific meetings.

The specific focus of this workshop effort is on understanding the social and technical dimensions of new technologies. The goal is to develop a research agenda that will help us understand the challenges of shaping emergent technologies in ways that result in good jobs for a wide range of U.S. workers. This includes a workshop that will bring together expert scientists to consider (1) how the changing organization of work and technology affects income inequality; (2) how decisions are made in developing artificial intelligence and processes for human-technology partnerships; (3) how to develop methods for assessing emerging technologies in terms of likely work satisfaction and inequality in employment outcomes; and (4) how workforce development and economic systems can help make high-paying stable jobs widely available. The second workshop will include stakeholders and will focus on how to use these ideas at the local level.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project convened a series of workshops and conferences to bring together knowledge from social sciences, computer sciences, and engineering to further understanding of emerging technologies, equity, and the future of work. In particular, the project focused on Artificial Intelligence (AI) powered technologies and related knowledge. The project explored automation and replication of historical inequalities in labor markets in the US, analyzing how AI may have potential for empowering broader labor market participation as well as the need to monitor how knowledge production is being imagined in order to promote equity, and the geographical and regional elements of innovation and equity including in automated vehicle development.

The workshops for convening discussion of these topics included: 1) a half-day interdisciplinary workshop for on campus experts at University of Massachusetts Amherst (UMass) on emerging tech, equity, and the future of work; 2) a two day workshop at UMass convening national experts across the US from social sciences, computer sciences, and engineering for discussion of emerging technologies/AI, racial equity and the future of work; 3) a one day workshop in Boston convening stakeholders from for-profit, non-profit and public sector organizations to discuss the practical implications of the findings from the expert workshops on the future of work; 4) a two day workshop for sociologists working on AI/emerging tech research to develop a research agenda for a sociology of AI (planned to be held at Drexel University in Pennsylvania, moved online when Covid-19 outbreak hit).

Findings from the workshops were reported in the project report, available at the following url (as of December 2020): http://rbr.cs.umass.edu/htf/NSF-Workshop-Report.pdf . See publication list for this award for other published discussion of the findings. The participants at these workshops recognized that we are at a critical inflection point with technology and the future of work. The increasing use of automation in the workplace will continue to eliminate, create, and transform jobs. In the absence of a conscious effort to understand and proactively address questions of equity in the design, production, and dissemination of new technologies, it is likely that automation will exacerbate racial, gender, and class inequalities. Yet there is hope that raising awareness of the potentially negative consequences can encourage AI designers to think more proactively and holistically when developing new platforms. Scholars can play a critical role in raising awareness of the distributional impacts of technological change and in advocating for more inclusive and equitable approaches to the design and deployment of new technologies. This project also found that an interdisciplinary approach is needed to address the intertwined challenges of understanding emerging technologies and equity in workplaces. If current AI research efforts in academia and industry do not draw on the expertise of social scientists, there is a danger of reproducing existing inequalities in both the processes and products of that development. Likewise, if current social science efforts to understand inequality do not draw on the expertise of computer scientists and engineers who are designing new work systems, the understanding can only be partial.

The broader impacts of this project have already begun as investigators have engaged stakeholders in the conversation as well as academic experts and students. For example, PI Laurel Smith-Doerr was invited to present key findings from this project to industry leaders at a large Catalyst.org conference on Gender and the Future of Work, held at the Lockheed Corp headquarters in Washington DC in December 2019. This project has outlined research agendas that will generate knowledge expected to have practical implications for improving work organization structures and practices.
